awd_titl_txt: Direct Conversion of Carbon into Diamond and Useful Micro and Nanostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: This project focuses on direct conversion of carbon into diamond at ambient temperatures and atmospheric pressures in air. By NCSU's transformative approach, carbon can be converted into so-called Q-carbon (named because of laser quenching) and diamond in a variety of useful nanostructures and microstructures in the form of nanoscale needles, microscale needles, nanoscale dots, microscale crystals, and large-area single-crystal films on practical substrates such as sapphire, glass and heat-sensitive polymers. These microscale and nanoscale structures have potential applications, e.g., as cutting tools and high-speed machining; and in high-power, quantum computing devices, and biomedical devices. The goals in this very critical stage are to develop a basic understanding and address issues related to scale-up and manufacturing of diamond-related products. This project has a strong education value through training of graduate students in this exciting new area in collaboration with NC A&T faculty and students.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This research addresses fundamental understanding and investigations of basic mechanisms involved in the direct conversion of carbon into diamond. By using nanosecond pulsed laser irradiation, carbon is melted in a highly undercooled state at 4000 K (over 1000 K below the melting point of carbon). This state is then quenched to form Q-carbon (a new phase of carbon) or diamond or a mixture of both; the result depends on the degree of undercooling. Q-carbon has many exciting new properties, including ferromagnetism, super hardness and enhanced field emission for next-generation displays. Q-carbon is converted into diamond by laser irradiation with a second laser pulse. By controlling interfacial instability during rapid quenching nanodots, microdots, nanoneedles and microneedles are created with a single nanosecond laser pulse; the entire process is completed in less than two hundred nanoseconds. This novel approach provides an inexpensive way to convert carbon into diamond and harvest various structures conveniently for a variety of applications. This research expands our fundamental knowledge base on laser-solid interactions and transient thermal processing of materials, and on the critical role of structure, defects and chemistry in the properties of novel Q-carbon and diamond-based structures.

por.por_cntn:
The reduction of carbon footprint in the US and the planet Earth as a whole is the highest priority to sustain the quality of life for humankind. This project accomplished a direct conversion of carbon into diamond at ambient temperatures and atmospheric pressures in air. By this transformative approach, carbon is converted directly into diamond or a new phase of carbon (named Q-carbon) by using nanosecond laser melting of carbon and quenching into a variety of useful nanostructures and microstructures in the form of nanoneedles, microneedles, nanodots, and microcrystals on practical substrates such as sapphire, glass and heat-sensitive polymers. These micro and nanostructures have applications ranging from cutting tools and high-speed machining to high-power devices and quantum computing to biomedical applications. The mechanism of conversion involves melting of carbon in a highly undercooled state and rapid quenching, where the whole process is completed in less than one-fifth of millionth of a second by using twenty-nanosecond pulsed laser. The laser melting and quenching process have been modeled to predict the details of heating, melting and quenching. The modeling results have been correlated with observed microstructures and nanostructures of diamond. Atomic structure of these micro- and nanostructures was determined using high-resolution transmission and scanning electron microscopy techniques, and bonding characteristics by high-resolution Raman and electron-energy-loss spectroscopy techniques.  This novel approach provides a very inexpensive way to convert carbon into diamond and harvest various structures conveniently for a variety of applications. This research expands our fundamental knowledge base on laser-solid interactions and transient thermal processing of materials, and on the critical role of structure, defects and chemistry in the properties of novel Q-carbon and novel diamond-based structures. This project has a strong educational component through training graduate students in this exciting new area in collaboration with NC A&T faculty and students. This research project has resulted in five journal papers and equal number of International Conference papers and presentations.
